entry.title: Towards Safe Policy Improvement for Non-Stationary MDPs

link.title: Towards Safe Policy Improvement for Non-Stationary MDPs

entry.content:
This post is based on a NeurIPS 2020 paper that I worked on with Scott Jordan, Georgios Theocharous, Martha White, and Philip Thomas. Here are the links for the paper and the code.

Motivation and probelm

  • Example scenarios
  • Ask the two main questions

Forecasting

  • Compare stationary and non-stationary (Two new images)
  • Generlizing thes tatioanry setting
  • Raise the question that will lead to off-policy

Overall methodology

something something

  • Forecasting (add image)
  • Gradient computation
  • benefits

Searching for a candidate policy

  • Discuss

Empirical performance


  • Plots and results

Open questions

  • Discuss variance reduction briefly
  • Better off-policy methods OPE
  • Better Time-series methods

entry.summary: How do we create model-free algorithms that can search for a good policy in a non-stationary MDP?

entry.title: Optimizing for the Future in Non-Stationary MDPs

link.title: Optimizing for the Future in Non-Stationary MDPs

entry.content:
This post is based on an ICML 2020 paper that I worked on with Georgios Theocharous , Shiv Shankar, Martha White, Sridhar Mahadevan, and Philip Thomas. Here are the links for the paper and the code.

How do we create model-free algorithms that can search for a good policy in a non-stationary MDP?

  • Example scenarios
  • Ask the two main questions

A time-series perspective

  • Compare stationary and non-stationary (Two new images)
  • Generlizing thes tatioanry setting
  • Raise the question that will lead to off-policy

Optimizing the future performance

something something

  • Forecasting (add image)
  • Least-squares regression as a differntiable operation
  • Generalizes stationary setting
  • Gradient computation
  • benefits

An intriguing behavior

  • Discuss
  • How do we mitigate variance?

Empirical performance


  • Plots and results

Open questions

  • Discuss variance reduction briefly
  • Better off-policy methods OPE
  • Better Time-series methods

Inline HTML elements

HTML defines a long list of available inline tags, a complete list of which can be found on the Mozilla Developer Network.

  • To bold text, use <strong>.
  • To italicize text, use <em>.
  • Abbreviations, like HTML should use <abbr>, with an optional title attribute for the full phrase.
  • Citations, like â€” Mark otto, should use <cite>.
  • Deleted text should use <del> and inserted text should use <ins>.
  • Superscript text uses <sup> and subscript text uses <sub>.

Most of these elements are styled by browsers with few modifications on our part.
